Cantor conceived set theory in a sequence of six papers published in the Mathematische Annalen during the five year period 1879â€“1884. In the fifth of these papers, published in 1883,1 he stated as a law of thought (Denkgesetz) that every set can be well-ordered or, more precisely, that it is always possible to bring any well-defined set into the form of a well-ordered set. Now to call it a law of thought was implicitly to claim self-evidence for it, but he must have given up that claim at some point, because in the 1890s he made an unsuccessful attempt at demonstrating the well-ordering principle.2

The first to succeed in doing so was Zermelo,3 although, as a prerequisite of the demonstration, he had to introduce a new principle, which came to be called the principle of choice (Prinzip der Auswahl) respectively the axiom of choice (Axiom der Auswahl) in his two4 papers5 from 1908. His first paper on the subject, published in 1904, consists of merely three pages, excerpted by Hilbert from a letter which he had received from Zermelo. The letter is dated 24 September 1904, and the excerpt begins by saying that the demonstration came out of discussions with Erhard Schmidt during the preceding week, which means that we can safely date the appearance of the axiom of choice and the demonstration of the well-ordering theorem to September 1904.

Brief as it was, Zermeloâ€™s paper gave rise to what is presumably the most lively discussion among mathematicians on the validity, or acceptability, of a mathematical axiom that has ever taken place. Within a couple of years, written contributions to this discussion were published by Felix Bernstein, Schoenflies, Hamel, Hessenberg, and Hausdorff in Germany; Baire, Borel, Hadamard, Lebesgue, Richard, and PoincarÃ© in France; Hobson, Hardy, Jourdain, and Russell in England; Julius KÃ¶nig in Hungary; Peano in Italy, and Brouwer in the Netherlands.6 Zermelo responded to those of these contributions that were critical, which was a majority, in a second paper from 1908. This second paper also contains a new proof of the well-ordering theorem, less intuitive or less perspicuous, it has to be admitted, than the original proof, as well as a new formulation of the axiom of choice, a formulation which will play a crucial role in the following considerations.

Despite the strength of the initial opposition against it, Zermeloâ€™s axiom of choice gradually came to be accepted, mainly because it was needed at an early stage in the development of several branches of mathematics, not only set theory, but also topology, algebra and functional analysis, for example. Towards the end of the thirties, it had become firmly established and was made part of the standard mathematical curriculum in the form of Zornâ€™s lemma.7

The intuitionists, on the other hand, rejected the axiom of choice from the very beginning. Baire, Borel, and Lebesgue were all critical of it in their contributions to the correspondence, which was published under the title Cinq lettres sur la thÃ©orie des ensembles in 1905.8 Brouwerâ€™s thesis from 1907 contains a section on the well-ordering principle in which it is treated in a dismissive fashion (â€˜of course there is no motivation for this at allâ€™) and in which, following Borel,9 he belittles Zermeloâ€™s proof of it from the axiom of choice.10 No further discussion of the axiom of choice seems to be found in either Brouwerâ€™s or Heytingâ€™s writings. Presumably, it was regarded by them as a prime example of a nonconstructive principle.

It therefore came as a surprise when, as late as in 1967, Bishop stated,

A choice function exists in constructive mathematics, because a choice is implied by the very meaning of existence,11

although, in the terminology that he himself introduced in the subsequent chapter, he ought to have said â€˜choice operationâ€™ rather than â€˜choice functionâ€™. What he had in mind was clearly that the truth of

In 1975, soon after Bishopâ€™s vindication of the constructive axiom of choice, Diaconescu proved that, in topos theory, the law of excluded middle follows from the axiom of choice.12 Now, topos theory being an intuitionistic theory, albeit impredicative, this is on the surface of it incompatible with Bishopâ€™s observation because of the constructive unacceptability of the law of excluded middle. There is therefore a need to investigate how the constructive axiom of choice, validated by the Brouwer-Heyting-Kolmogorov interpretation, is related to Zermeloâ€™s axiom of choice on the one hand and to the topos-theoretic axiom of choice on the other.

To this end, using constructive type theory as our instrument of analysis, let us simply try to prove Zermeloâ€™s axiom of choice. This attempt should of course fail, but in the process of making it we might at least be able to discover what it is that is really objectionable about it. So what was Zermeloâ€™s axiom of choice? In the original paper from 1904, he gave to it the following formulation,

Jeder Teilmenge Mâ€²M'Mâ€² denke man sich ein beliebiges Element m1â€²m'_1m1â€²â€‹ zugeordnet, das in Mâ€²M'Mâ€² selbst vorkommt und das â€ausgezeichneteâ€ Element von Mâ€²M'Mâ€² genannt werden mÃ¶ge.13

Here Mâ€²M'Mâ€² is an arbitrary subset, which contains at least one element, of a given set M.M.M. What is surprising about this formulation is that there is nothing objectionable about it from a constructive point of view. Indeed, the distinguished element m1â€²m'_1m1â€²â€‹ can be taken to be the first projection of the proof of the existential proposition (âˆƒx:M)(âˆƒx : M)(âˆƒx:M)Mâ€²(x),M'(x),Mâ€²(x), which says that the subset Mâ€²M'Mâ€² of MMM contains at least one element. This means that one would have to go into the demonstration of the well-ordering theorem in order to determine exactly what are its nonconstructive ingredients.

Instead of doing that, I shall turn to the formulation of the axiom of choice that Zermelo favoured in his second paper on the well-ordering theorem from 1908,

Eine Menge S,S,S, welche in eine Menge getrennter Teile A,A,A, B,B,B, C,C,C, â€¦â€¦â€¦ zerfÃ¤llt, deren jeder mindestens ein Element enthÃ¤lt, besitzt mindestens eine Untermenge S1,S_1,S1â€‹, welche mit jedem der betrachteten Teile A,A,A, B,B,B, C,C,C, â€¦â€¦â€¦ genau ein Element gemein hat.14

The following are equivalent in constructive type theory:

Another indication that the extenÂ­sional axiom of choice is the correct type-theoretic rendering of Zermeloâ€™s axiom of choice comes from constructive set theory. Peter Aczel has shown how to interpret the language of Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory in constructive type theory, this interpretation being the natural constructive version of the cumulative hierarchy, and investigated what set-theoretic principles that become validated under that interpretation.17 But one may also ask, conversely, what principle, or principles, that have to be adjoined to constructive type theory in order to validate a specific set-theoretic axiom. In particular, this may be asked about the formalised version of the axiom of choice that Zermelo made part of his own axiomatisation of set theory. The answer is as follows.

Theorem II.

When constructive type theory is strengthened by the extenÂ­sional axiom of choice, the set-theoretic axiom of choice becomes validated under the Aczel interpretation.

Corollary.

When constructive type theory (including one universe and the WWW-operation) is strengthened by the extenÂ­sional axiom of choice, it interprets all of ZFC.

Proof.

We already know from Aczel that ZF is equivalent to CZF +++ EM.18 Hence ZFC is equivalent to CZF +++ EM +++ AC. But, by Diaconescuâ€™s theorem as transferred to constructive set theory by Goodman and Myhill, the law of excluded middle follows from the axiom of choice in the context of constructive set theory.19 It thus suffices to interpret CZF +++ AC in CTT +++ ExtAC, and this is precisely what the Aczel interpretation does, by the previous theorem.

Another way of reaching the same conclusion is to interchange the order of the last two steps in the proof just given, arguing instead that ZFC === CZF +++ EM +++ AC is interpretable in CTT +++ EM +++ ExtAC by the previous theorem, and then appealing to the type-theoretic version of Diaconescuâ€™s theorem, according to which the law of excluded middle follows from the extenÂ­sional axiom of choice in the context of constructive type theory.20 The final conclusion is anyhow that ZFC is interpretable in CTT +++ ExtAC.

When Zermeloâ€™s axiom of choice is formulated in the context of constructive type theory instead of Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory, it appears as ExtAC, the extenÂ­sional axiom of choice

(âˆ€i:I)(âˆƒx:S)A(i,x)â†’(âˆƒf:Iâ†’S)(Ext(f)âˆ§(âˆ€i:I)A(i,f(i))),(âˆ€i : I)(âˆƒx : S)A(i, x) â†’ (âˆƒf : I â†’ S)(\text{Ext}(f) âˆ§ (âˆ€i : I)A(i, f(i))),(âˆ€i:I)(âˆƒx:S)A(i,x)â†’(âˆƒf:Iâ†’S)(Ext(f)âˆ§(âˆ€i:I)A(i,f(i))),

where

Ext(f)=(âˆ€i,j:I)(iâ‰Ijâ†’f(i)â‰Sf(j)),\text{Ext}(f) = (âˆ€i, j : I)(i â‰_I j â†’ f(i) â‰_S f(j)),Ext(f)=(âˆ€i,j:I)(iâ‰Iâ€‹jâ†’f(i)â‰Sâ€‹f(j)),

and it then becomes manifest what is the problem with it: it breaks the principle that you cannot get something from nothing. Even if the relation A(i,x)A(i, x)A(i,x) is extenÂ­sional with respect to its two arguments, the truth of the antecedent (âˆ€i:I)(âˆ€i : I)(âˆ€i:I)(âˆƒx:S)(âˆƒx : S)(âˆƒx:S)A(i,x),A(i, x),A(i,x), which does guarantee the existence of a choice function f:Iâ†’Sf : I â†’ Sf:Iâ†’S satisfying (âˆ€i:I)(âˆ€i : I)(âˆ€i:I)A(i,f(i)),A(i, f(i)),A(i,f(i)), is not enough to guarantee the extenÂ­sionality of the choice function, that is, the truth of Ext(f).(f).(f). Thus the problem with Zermeloâ€™s axiom of choice is not the existence of the choice function but its extenÂ­sionality, and this is not visible within an extenÂ­sional framework, like Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory, where all functions are by definition extenÂ­sional.

If we want to ensure the extenÂ­sionality of the choice function, the antecedent clause of the extenÂ­sional axiom of choice has to be strengthened. The natural way of doing this is to replace ExtAC by AC!, the axiom of unique choice, or no choice,

which is as valid as the intenÂ­sional axiom of choice. Indeed, assume (âˆ€i:I)(âˆ€i : I)(âˆ€i:I)(âˆƒ!x:S)(âˆƒ!x : S)(âˆƒ!x:S)A(i,x)A(i, x)A(i,x) to be true. Then, by the intenÂ­sional axiom of choice, there exists a choice function f:Iâ†’Sf : I â†’ Sf:Iâ†’S satisfying (âˆ€i:I)(âˆ€i : I)(âˆ€i:I)A(i,f(i)).A(i, f(i)).A(i,f(i)). Because of the uniqueness condition, such a function f:Iâ†’Sf : I â†’ Sf:Iâ†’S is necessarily extenÂ­sional. For suppose that i,j:Ii, j : Ii,j:I are such that iâ‰Iji â‰_I jiâ‰Iâ€‹j is true. Then A(i,f(i))A(i, f(i))A(i,f(i)) and A(j,f(j))A(j, f(j))A(j,f(j)) are both true. Hence, by the extenÂ­sionality of A(i,x)A(i, x)A(i,x) in its first argument, so is A(i,f(j)).A(i, f(j)).A(i,f(j)). The uniqueness condition now guarantees that f(i)â‰Sf(j),f(i) â‰_S f(j),f(i)â‰Sâ€‹f(j), that is, that f:Iâ†’Sf : I â†’ Sf:Iâ†’S is extenÂ­sional. The axiom of unique choice AC! may be considered as the valid form of extenÂ­sional choice, as opposed to ExtAC, which lacks justification.

-- axiom of unique choice

The inability to distinguish between the intenÂ­sional and the extenÂ­sional axiom of choice has led to oneâ€™s taking the need for the axiom of choice in proving that the union of a countable sequence of countable sets is again countable, that the real numbers, defined as Cauchy sequences of rational numbers, are Cauchy complete, etc., as a justification of Zermeloâ€™s axiom of choice. As Zermelo himself wrote towards the end of the short paper in which he originally introduced the axiom of choice,

Dieses logische Prinzip lÃ¤ÃŸt sich zwar nicht auf ein noch einfacheres zurÃ¼ckfÃ¼hren, wird aber in der mathematischen Deduktion Ã¼berall unbedenklich angewendet.21

What Zermelo wrote here about the omnipresent, and often subconscious, use of the axiom of choice in mathematical proofs is incontrovertible, but it concerns the constructive, or intenÂ­sional, version of it, which follows almost immediately from the strong rule of existential elimination. It cannot be taken as a justification of his own version of the axiom of choice, including as it does the extenÂ­sionality of the choice function.

Within an extenÂ­sional foundational framework, like topos theory or constructive set theory, it is not wholly impossible to formulate a counterpart of the constructive axiom of choice, despite of its intenÂ­sional character, but it becomes complicated. In topos theory, there is the axiom that there are enough projectives, which is to say that every object is the surjective image of a projective object, and, in constructive set theory, Aczel has introduced the analogous axiom that every set has a base.22 Roughly speaking, this is to say that every set is the surjective image of a set for which the axiom of choice holds. The technical complication of these axioms speaks to my mind for an intenÂ­sional foundational framework, like constructive type theory, in which the intuitive argument why the axiom of choice holds on the Brouwer-Heyting-Kolmogorov interpretation is readily formalized, and in which whatever extenÂ­sional notions that are needed can be built up, in agreement with the title of Martin Hofmannâ€™s thesis, ExtenÂ­sional Constructs in IntenÂ­sional Type Theory.23 ExtenÂ­sionality does not come for free.

Finally, since this is only a couple of weeks from the centenary of Zermeloâ€™s first formulation of the axiom of choice, it may not be out of place to remember the crucial role it has played for the formalisation of both Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory and constructive type theory. In the case of set theory, there was the need for Zermelo of putting his proof of the well-ordering theorem on a formally rigorous basis, whereas, in the case of type theory, there was the intuitively convincing argument which made axiom of choice evident on the constructive interpretation of the logical operations, an argument which nevertheless could not be faithfully formalised in any then existing formal system.

article_metadata.title: P.Â Martin-LÃ¶f (2006) 100 years of Zermeloâ€™s axiom of choice: What was the problem with it? â€” Machine Intuitionist

hook: Zermelo's Axiom of Choice, a century-old cornerstone of mathematics, has sparked enduring debate.  This article delves into Per Martin-LÃ¶f's 2006 work, utilizing Agda programming language to illuminate the axiom's inherent complexities and lingering problems.

top_comments.author: LudwigNagasena
top_comments.text: How is it different from using ZF as a meta-theory to study ZF(C)? Is there anything special about category theory vis-Ã -vis ZF as a meta-theory? You're not arguing about ontology or the nature of truth, because you've picked category theory as your ontology just like you could pick ZF or ZFC.

top_comments.author: karmakurtisaani
top_comments.text: Yeah, it's important to think of these axioms as choosing the rules of the game, rather than what intuitively makes sense. The real question is if playing the game produces useful results.

top_comments.author: woopsn
top_comments.text:
Axioms are also introduced in practical terms just to make proofs and results "better". Usually we talk in terms of what propositions are provable, saying that indicates the strength/power of these assumptions, but beyond this there are issues of proof length and complexity.

For example in arithmetic without induction, roughly, theorems remain the same (those which can still be expressed) but may have exponentially longer proofs because of the loss of those `âˆ€n P(n)`-type propositions.

In this sense it does sometimes come back to intuition. If for all n we can prove P(n), then `âˆ€n P(n)` should be an acceptable proposition and doesn't really change "the game" we are trying to play. It just makes it more intuitive and playable.

top_comments.author: SabrinaJewson
top_comments.text:
Iâ€™m not sure what you mean by â€œtheorems remain the sameâ€. If you take away induction from Peano arithmetic, you get Robinson arithmetic, which has many more models, including (from https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4076545):

- â„• âˆª {âˆ}

- Cardinal arithmetic

- â„¤[x]âº

Obviously, not all theorems that are true for the natural numbers are true for cardinals, so it seems misleading to say that theorems remain the same. I also believe that the addition of induction increases the consistency strength of the theory, so itâ€™s not â€œjustâ€ a matter of expressing the theorems in a different way.

I would agree more for axioms that donâ€™t affect consistency strength, like foundation or choice (over the rest of the ZF axioms).

top_comments.author: karmakurtisaani
top_comments.text: Good point. I would argue, however, that having nicer proofs is a "useful" result of the game.

top_comments.author: btilly
top_comments.text:
Spoken like a true formalist.

It doesn't really have to mean anything when we say that the reals are a larger set than the natural numbers - that's just the conclusion of the game that we are playing.

What fraction of people who "know" that there are more reals than natural numbers, do you think really understand that this is not an eternal verity of mathematics, but only a conclusion that follows from a particular set of rules that we're playing the mathematics game with?

top_comments.author: skissane
top_comments.text:
> What fraction of people who "know" that there are more reals than natural numbers, do you think really understand that this is not an eternal verity of mathematics, but only a conclusion that follows from a particular set of rules that we're playing the mathematics game with?

The claim that there are more reals than naturals holds given classical ZF(C) set theory. But there are alternative set theories in which the reals are countable, e.g. NFU+AxCount. These alternative set theories ensure all reals are countable by rendering Cantorâ€™s diagonalisation argument invalid, since their axioms are too weak to validate it. But, they contain all the same reals as the high school mathematics concept of â€œrealsâ€. So, there are many reals, and that some of them are countable and others are not are indeed â€œeternal truthsâ€ (it is an eternal truth that whatever axioms have the consequences they do), but the everyday (non-expert) concept of reals isnâ€™t any of them in particular - and it is unclear if the dominance of classical notions in mainstream professional mathematics was historically inevitable or a historical accident - maybe, on the other side of the galaxy, there exists some alien civilisation, in which different foundations of mathematics are mainstream, because their mathematics took a different evolutionary course from ours - maybe for them, reals are classically countable, and uncountability is an exotic notion belonging to alternative foundations of mathematics

top_comments.author: btilly
top_comments.text:
As I pointed out at https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=44271589, there are systems that can accept Cantor's argument, without concluding that there are more reals than rational numbers.

As you point out, there are many mathematical systems that contain all of the numbers in the high school mathematics concept of "reals". Since those with a high school understanding of reals do not know which of those systems they would agree with, they should not be asked to accept as true, any results that hold in only some of those systems.

And that is why I don't like mathematicians telling lay audiences that there are more reals than rationals.

top_comments.author: zozbot234
top_comments.text: "Cantor's diagonalization argument" is best understood as a mere special case of Lawvere's fixed-point theorem. Lawvere's theorem is really the meat of the argument, and it's also the part that is very easy for exotic systems to "accept", since it's close to a purely logical argument. Whether these systems truly accept "Cantor's argument" is perhaps only a matter of perception and intuition, that people may perhaps disagree about.

top_comments.author: btilly
top_comments.text:
It does not matter what your best understanding of Cantor's diagonalization argument is. In some mathematical systems it means, "there are more reals than natural numbers", and in others it means, "the reals encode self-reference in a more direct way than the natural numbers do".

The result is that it is possible for the acceptance of the argument to lead to very different consequences about what we then conclude.

analysis.analysis:
**1. Summary:**

The provided text is a fragment of an Agda formalization of mathematical concepts related to equivalence relations and set theory, focusing on the definition and properties of equivalence relations and their relationship to equality.  The accompanying comments discuss the philosophical implications of axiomatic systems in mathematics, particularly concerning the Axiom of Choice and the implications of different axiomatic choices on theorems and the interpretation of results like Cantor's diagonalization argument.


**2. Key Points:**

* **Agda Formalization:** The core text presents code written in the Agda proof assistant, defining concepts like equivalence relations (Reflexive, Symmetric, Transitive), and demonstrating their properties.  This showcases formal verification of mathematical statements.
* **Axiomatic Systems and Choice:** The comments extensively debate the role of axioms in mathematics.  The discussion centers on the idea that axioms define the "rules of the game," and the "usefulness" of the resulting theorems is a key criterion for evaluating an axiomatic system, rather than an inherent truth value.
* **Cantor's Diagonalization and Alternatives:**  The comments specifically address Cantor's diagonalization argument, suggesting it's a special case of a more general theorem (Lawvere's fixed-point theorem) and highlighting that its interpretation (e.g., the cardinality of reals vs. naturals) depends on the chosen axiomatic system.  The existence of mathematical systems where Cantor's argument leads to different conclusions is emphasized.


**3. Discussion Highlights:**

* **Formalism vs. Intuition:** The comments reveal a strong formalist perspective, emphasizing that mathematical truths are consequences of chosen axioms, not inherent properties of reality.  The debate revolves around whether the "niceness" or "usefulness" of proofs and results is a sufficient justification for choosing one axiomatic system over another.
* **Meta-theoretical Considerations:** Comment 1 raises the question of using different meta-theories (like ZF or category theory) to study set theory, suggesting that the choice of meta-theory doesn't necessarily impact the ontological status of the results.
* **Multiple Interpretations of Theorems:** The discussion around Cantor's diagonalization argument demonstrates that the same mathematical argument can have different interpretations depending on the underlying axiomatic framework. This challenges the notion of a single, universally valid interpretation of mathematical results.
* **The Role of Proof Length and Complexity:** Comment 3 introduces the practical consideration of proof length and complexity as factors influencing the choice of axioms, beyond just provability.  This highlights the practical aspects of mathematical work alongside the philosophical ones.
